events.text:
Made by Viridino Studios (@ViridinoStudios)

Mateus Ferreira - Programmer
Twitter: @BonzerKitten
E-mail: ferreiramoreiramateus@gmail.com

Wesley Andrade - Artist
Twitter: @andrart7
E-mail: wesleymatos1989@gmail.com

Made with the support of patrons on https://www.patreon.com/viridinostudios
How much time has passed since the game has been opened.
How much time has passed since the round started.
Whether or not the player is alive.
How large and tall the grid will be in cells.
How many mines the grid will contain.
How large and tall each cell is.
The position where the first grid cell will be created, others will follow along.

children.text: Create a grid of cells, based on a few pre-definied properties (grid size and cell size).
To make sure all cells will be available for picking, it's important to wait a bit before placing the mines, so a timer is very useful here.
Once the timer is complete, use a permutation table (sequence of numbers randomly ordered) to pick random cells that will be used as hidden mines.

actions.text: Optionally spawn a debug eye on top of each mine, so they're visible while testing (disabled by default).

children.text: Allow the player to interact with the cells, but only while he's alive.

actions.text: Count how much time has passed since the round started and display it in the HUD.

children.text: If the cursor is on top of a closed cell, positionate the cursor on top of it, otherwise move the cursor outside the visible area.
If the cursor is released while touching a cell, check its surroundings.

events.text: Check the surroundings of a specific cell based on its UID

children.text: Only open and check the surroundings of the cell if it hasn't been opened yet.
How many cells are nearby the chosen cell.
If the chosen cell is a mine, then ignore the surroundings and simply detonate it, resulting in a game over.

actions.text: Reveal the mine.
Indicate the detonated mine by creating a sight pointing to it. The point also rotates and bounces to better call the player's attention.
Remove the cursor from the screen, since it won't be used during the current round.
Change the smiley to a sad face, so the player know's he lost the game.
Since a mine has just exploded, change the window name to "Explosion.exe" just as a small easter egg.
Create a constantly growing reveal circle that will show the content of unopened cells in the grid.
Shake the screen for a more impactful effect.
Start the explosion sequence, where a bunch of explosions will be shown in the screen.

children.text: However, if the chosen cell is not a mine, count how many cells are surrounding it.
Spawn a separate collider, which will make it it easier to make collision tests with other cells, since it's a completely different object and not just an instance.
Loop through all surrounding cells in a 3x3 area, but avoid the chosen cell by checking if at least one of the loops is not equal to zero.
If the collider is indeed overlapping a mine, then add one to the nearby mines counter.
Once the collision checking is over, destroy the collider, since it won't be used anymore.
If there's at least one mine nearby the chosen cell, update its local nearby mines counter and display it with a different animation.
However, if there are absolutely no mines nearby the chosen cell, turn it into a flying debri and check if there are more lone cells around it.

actions.text: All debri properties are slightly randomized for a more dynamic effect when multiple cells are destroyed in a row.
Shake the screen for a more impactful effect.

children.text: At last, check if there are only mines remaining in the grid. If so, notify the player of his victory.

actions.text: Prevent the player from interacting with the remaining mines by pretending he has lost.

events.text: Open the area around a specific cell, by checking if there are more lone cells around it.

actions.text: Display an empty cell animation.
A small timer is important to prevent the game from lagging due to a huge combination of loops in a single frame, it also create a very visually appealing cascade effect.

events.text: Once the timer is over, open the area around the cell with a similar technique to the previous one.

children.text: Spawn a separate collider, which will make it it easier to make collision tests with other cells, since it's a completely different object and not just an instance.
Loop through all surrounding cells in a 3x3 area, but avoid the chosen cell by checking if at least one of the loops is not equal to zero.
If the collider is overlapping a cell that is not a mine, check its surroundings as well, resulting in a cascade effect that will clean the grid as much as possible.
Once the collision checking is over, destroy the collider, since it won't be used anymore.
How many explosions were displayed already.

actions.text: Prevent the player from interacting with the remaining mines.
Reset the explosion counter, so it can be triggered multiple times if necessary.
Create an initial explosion in the chosen position.
Start a timer to trigger the next explosion after a small amount of time.

children.text: Loop through all cells and display the remaining mines in the grid.
Once the the explosion times is over, increase the explosion counter and check if it should stop or create a new explosion.
If the explosion counter has reached its limit, then stop the timer, so no more explosions are created.

Otherwise, create a new explosion on top of a random cell. A random position like "random(0, 10)" could've been used here as well, but picking a random cell instance makes sure no explosion will be created outside the grid in a more intuitive way.
Once an explosion is create in the scene, create four additional fire balls around it that will fly in completely random directions.

actions.text: Destroy the fire ball after a small amount of time.

children.text: Leave a trail of smoke behind the fire ball while it's flying.
Revealing underneath the blocks
Restarts the game if the player touches the smiley icon, but only if the player is not alive anymore.
Start a tween animation based on a strength and duration values, which will be used to change the layout angle, creating a dynamic screen shake effect.
When the animation of a particles object is over, destroy it to avoid any sort of CPU overload.
